file_content.text: Yes, sir.
Acknowledged.
Yes, sir? Did you need something?
Sir, if you need something, just say so. Otherwise, we should get moving.
Sir. My equipment and personal effects have been stowed in full accordance with transport code section two.
If I may say so again, sir, it is truly an honor to be selected for Havoc Squad.
I'm glad to have you on the team, Dorne.
You'll do a great job.
Thank you very much, sir.
Clearly, our first assignment should be a welcome party.
[Flirt] How about a drink?
I appreciate the sentiment, but I have a great deal of intelligence to catch up on.
We never know what we're going to run into from one op to the next.
Be ready for the unexpected.
Yes, the operation on Taris was a clear example of that.
You're only here because of General Garza.
I didn't choose you.
Hmph. Well, I am here, so we might as well both make the best of the situation.
I intend to begin reviewing and memorizing all relevant dossiers and intelligence reports on our assignment immediately.
If I discover any points of confusion or areas where I believe I can contribute, I'll submit a full 587-B report.
Carry on, Dorne.
Very good.
Yes, sir.
Sure, the old 587-B. Sounds good, Dorne.
Um... okay.
Thank you, sir. I'll get on with my review.
Forget the reports. If you want to tell me something, just tell me.
You need to lighten up.
Hmm. If you wish, sir.
So... not to rush anything, but... would you be at all interested in raising children someday?
I'm not suggesting any time in the immediate future, of course. But... someday, perhaps?
I'd love to raise kids someday, Elara.
Kids would be great.
I think I would, too. It would mean a lot to me to have a real family again, someday.
I hadn't really thought about it.
I'm not sure.
To be honest, it hadn't crossed my mind until recently, either.
I am not dealing with kids, Elara.
No way!
You say that now. But someday, when the fighting is finally done... you might change your mind.
I think I would be an excellent mother to our children. I could teach them all about medicine, biology, legal terminology...
I could even teach them about their brave and noble father, who took the stuffy Imperial no one liked and made her the happiest woman in the galaxy.
Any kids you raised would be smart, and brave, and have a good conscience.
You'd be a great mom.
Hm. I don't think I'd be the only good influence on them.
That sounds like a good story to me. You're not that stuck-up, though.
"Brave and noble", huh?
Hm, well, I forgot to mention that this man is also unusually patient. And generous....
...and handsome, of course. Very handsome.
Like I said, I don't think it's a step we should take anytime soon. But someday.
I still don't think it's for me, Elara.
Yeah, we'll see.
Fair enough--I won't press the issue.
But you will change your mind eventually. And when you do, you'll be as good a father as you are a husband and commander.
Tell me, sir: do you think you'll have children someday?
I can only imagine the young soldiers and commanders you would raise. Future defenders of the Republic, one and all.
I'd be proud to see my kids serve the Republic.
I'd like that.
Certainly.
The idea of kids hadn't crossed my mind.
Never really thought about it.
There's no way I'm ever going to have children.
I'm not having kids.
Really? I think you'd make a splendid mother.
No? You would be an excellent father.
I could even tutor them for you: medicine, biology... Republic and military legal terminology.
I'd appreciate it, Elara.
That would be great.
You've been a true friend to me. I'd be more than happy to return the favor in the future.
What if they don't become soldiers, or doctors, or... lawyers?
What if they do something else?
Well, whatever they choose to do in life, I'll be glad to do whatever I can to help them.
Why are you talking about this?
This is weird.
Forgive me. I know it may seem random, but I was just thinking about what a true friend you've been to me.
I want to be that kind of friend for you, too. Someone you can always count on.
Anyway, we have plenty of work to do in the here and now--let's get to it.
I've been wondering what life will be like when the war finally ends.
I've always known that there will be peace eventually, but...
It'd be nice to finally take some vacation.
Maybe we'll get time off.
Hopefully there will be at least a few beautiful places left to visit.
People in the Empire even know the meaning of the word?
Do Imps know what peace is?
Absolutely. In the Empire, peace comes when all enemies are destroyed.
It's a big galaxy. There's always fighting somewhere.
"Peace" is relative.
True enough.
All that truly matters is that I have you with me, whatever the future brings.
I want you to be a part of my life, no matter what may come. I want to be with you forever.
Marry me, Elara. We'll face the future together.
Let's get married!
Is that your way of saying you want to marry me?
Uh, are you proposing?
Well... in the Empire, at least, it is still customary for the man to propose to the woman.
But if I want to be with you... and you want to be with me... then why not make it official?
In that case... Elara Dorne, will you marry me?
You're right.
We're together now. Why wouldn't we be together later?
We're already together.
That's just what I'm getting at. We're together now, and that's probably not changing anytime soon, so....
Why not make it official? Err, unless you aren't interested in marriage.
Let's make it official. Marry me.
I do want to marry you.
You mean it? I... oh, yes!
No good reason not to. Let's get married!
Sure, why not?
Heh, I love you....
Hm. We'll have to do things properly someday. A military ceremony, dress uniforms... do you think General Garza would officiate?
I doubt the general gets many opportunities like that these days.
Definitely.
All too true. I'll start composing a formal request. Form 5763W, if I'm not mistaken.
I'm sure we could convince her.
We'll twist her arm.
I hope so. She has such an authoritative speaking voice.
General Garza isn't really my first choice.
I'd rather get someone else.
Oh. Well, I'm sure we could find someone of suitable rank to perform the ceremony.
For now, just know I'm yours. Now and forever.
I'll always be with you.
And I'm yours.
The most beautiful girl in the galaxy, all to myself.
I'm so lucky.
No more sweet-talk. We've still got a war to win.
Enough sappy stuff.
Yes, yes. Duty calls.
I love you.
I love you, Elara, but marriage... it's not for me.
I'm not the marrying type.
"Not for you"? Fine. I understand. I hear you, loud and clear.
I won't trouble you any further, then. If you'll excuse me, I'm sure there are some reports somewhere on this ship that need filing.
Sir! The Journal published my article!
I've already received dozens of holomessages from medical officers in units across the galaxy. I never expected such a positive reaction.
That's fantastic news, Elara. You should feel very proud.
Congratulations!
I doubt anyone will be throwing accusations at you now.
From suspect to superstar.
I hadn't even thought of it that way.
Do you get anything for this? Credits, maybe?
Any money involved?
Certainly not.
I would never have learned so much if you hadn't brought me onto the squad. I really owe you a tremendous debt, sir.
Thank you. Truly.
Sir. I am ordered to report that I, Elara Dorne, personnel number 22-795, am no longer classified as a "person of concern."
The Personnel Division of the Army of the Galactic Republic has declared that I am to be treated as a fully protected legal citizen, effective immediately.
This is great news, Elara. I'm really happy for you.
You did it!
I couldn't have done it without all of your support.
You beat him, Elara! You're free!
You did it!
That I am, sir.
Tell me everything. What about Kalor?
What happened?
It's about time we put this junk behind us.
Finally.
I couldn't agree more.
Kalor never saw it coming. When I exercised my right under service code one to an immediate personnel hearing, he was literally speechless.
I demonstrated documentation for every moment of his pointless investigation. Once the man hours and expenditures were totalled, it came to thousands of credits wasted in wartime.
I can't believe it had really gone so far.
Incredible.
Yes. Even after I had gathered all of that evidence, the full scale of what had happened didn't settle in until I was presenting it in the hearing.
I assume Kalor won't be working for Personnel Division anymore.
Was he fired?
I'm not privy to his employment status, but I suspect you're right.
That kind of waste at a time like this is treason in my book.
Kalor should be shot.
Military law does stipulate that charges of treason can be drawn for systematic misuse of resources. Kalor's final tally didn't quite cross that threshold, however.
I still can't believe this day has finally come.
The suspicion, the reservations, the endless questions... they've been a part of my life for so long. But no more--I am a citizen of the Galactic Republic.
It must feel like you're starting a whole new life.
This will be a big change.
It does. And I have you to share it with.
It truly does.
It's great to see this happening for you.
I'm happy for you.
Thank you so much.
There will still be people who won't hear anything but your accent.
Don't get too excited yet.
Let them waste their time with doubts. I'll waste no more of mine.
I've never felt prouder to be serving the Republic.
Let's return to the front lines. I want to get back to doing my part!
Time to get this ship moving.
Sounds like a plan.
You don't need some time to let this all settle in?
Are you sure?
No. There's nowhere I'd rather be than fighting with my fellow soldiers of the Republic.
I could use a good scrap myself.
A real fight would be good.
I'll prepare my equipment, sir!
Sir. I'm afraid I need to request a brief leave of absence.
It's Kalor. He's attempting to exploit a loophole in investigative appeals process subsection four in order to reopen his "inquiry" without new cause.
What can we do to put an end to this?
How can we stop him?
A preemptive strike is the only option.
I think it's time to introduce that scumbag to the roomier end of an air lock.
That son of a....
That won't be necessary.
Exploiting the what in the what? Speak basic.
You're talking gibberish.
He's coming after me. Again.
I'm not going to give Kalor the time to carry his supposed "investigation" any further. I'm going to Coruscant.
I have every message, every report, every call recorded. It's time to demonstrate to Kalor's superiors exactly what his supposed "service" to the Republic has accomplished.
I'll come with you. With my word backing you up, you can't fail.
Let me help.
You're very kind to offer, sir. But I need to handle this myself--bringing a war hero along would seem like a diversionary tactic.
Knock 'em dead, Elara.
Good luck.
Whatever you're going to do, just be sure you keep it short.
Just make it fast.
I intend to.
I'll return as quickly as possible.
I'll set out as soon as you give the word.
I need to get something off of my chest.
Our work is quite dangerous, and of course the future is always uncertain....
You sound upset. What is it?
What's wrong?
I'm not upset. That... isn't it at all.
You're not still worried about Kalor, are you?
Is this about Kalor?
No, it's not about that. I mean, that is the sort of thing I mean, but... no.
Whatever you want to say, just say it.
Just spit it out.
I love you.
We risk our lives every day, and I couldn't let another moment pass without telling you how much I love you.
I love you too, Elara.
I love you, too.
I thought you were going to tell me something awful.
You really had me worried!
I'm sorry. I didn't mean to trouble you.
This is a bit fast for me.
Whoa, slow down there.
Fast? This is too... oh. I see.
I've said what I wanted to say. You obviously have no response, so let's just leave it at that.
I'm sorry, you just caught me off guard. I love you, Elara.
No, wait--I love you, too.
I can't tell you how much it means to hear you say it, too.
I got something for us. It took a great deal of research, and a quite a few holo-calls to some very important people.
Form 3578-K officially authorizes us to pursue a mutual romantic relationship. I was hoping we could sign it together.
I'm happy to make it official.
Of course.
Fantastic.
It's a bit weird, but if it makes you happy....
I guess so.
It does, sir. It takes a great weight off of my mind.
We shouldn't have to file a form to be in a relationship.
This is stupid.
I thought you'd know by now that I always prefer to do things by the book.
Now, then. Since that's out of the way, I was thinking... that is, if you have the time....
Just try and stop me.
Always.
I wouldn't dream of it.
Have the time for what?
Huh?
Me, of course.
The war can wait.
I'll make time.
I hoped you would say that.
My, my. So many reasons to love you, it's hard to pick.
Let's go face the galaxy together.
I never wanted to hurt you, Elara.
I'm sorry about this.
That's wonderful. Excuse me.
We're soldiers, Elara. We don't have room for love.
You're asking too much.
I'm sorry you feel that way. Excuse me.
Sir. I was just going over a research article I've been writing for the Armed Forces Medical Science Journal.
I'm... well, I'm a bit nervous about it, actually. I've never had an article published in the Journal--it's quite prestigious.
I've never seen you do a bad job at anything, Elara. Your article is sure to impress them.
I'm sure they'll like it.
I appreciate the vote of confidence.
What exactly did you write about?
Tell me about the article.
A simplified step-by-step process for rapidly assessing wounds and treatment options in combat situations. Just something I've developed during our various operations.
Why is this Journal thing so important?
What's the big deal?
It's the preeminent source of literature on medical techniques and technologies for military personnel--the cutting edge.
I may not hear back for some time. There's quite a bit of writing in the medical field at the moment--one of the side effects of wartime.
I'll just have to wait and see.
Sir? I was wondering if you've received any messages from Captain Kalor recently.
I've not heard anything since the situation with Ridu. I'm a bit concerned, to be honest.
Captain Kalor hasn't sent me any messages.
I haven't heard anything.
Hm. I suppose it's possible he's moved on to other cases, but I can't help but suspect that he's still planning something.
The less we hear from Kalor, the better.
This seems like a good thing.
It's been nice to take my mind off his accusations, but I doubt he's given up yet.
I guess Kalor finally gave up his idiotic crusade.
He must have grown a brain.
The man is determined. I can't believe he's given up.
I attempted to contact him for my standard activity report, but I was told that he's out of the office on an important assignment.
I can't help but wonder if I'm a part of that assignment. I don't look forward to finding out.
Whatever Kalor does, we'll deal with it.
We can handle him.
I know I can't take my mind off of you, either.
[Flirt] Can't blame him.
I'll hope Kalor's interests aren't quite the same as yours.
If Kalor's up to something, there's nothing we can do right now.
No point worrying about it.
You're right, of course.
I won't tolerate Kalor interfering with my squad again.
If so, he'll regret it.
Perhaps it won't come to that.
We have enough to deal with as it is. I shouldn't be thinking about problems that may not exist.
Sorry to trouble you, sir. Let's just get back to work.
Sir. There is a very important matter that requires your immediate attention.
I've noted numerous reports and personnel documents that the other members of the squad have failed to keep up-to-date.
I've collected the files into datapads--I suggest that the others take them off-ship to fill out. A change of scenery helps when completing reports, I think.
Sounds like a plan to me, Elara.
Proceed.
Very good, sir.
Sounds like we'll have the whole ship to ourselves....
[Flirt] Great plan.
Hm. Yes, I suppose that's true, isn't it? Please excuse me a moment, sir.
You don't need me to fill out any reports, do you?
Do I have to do anything?
No, sir. I need your help with a different matter. One moment, please.
So: based on past performance when filing reports, Jorgan will complete his tasks the fastest. I've estimated at least seventy-three minutes.
Do you think we can find a productive way to spend the time before us, sir?
Let's get straight to work.
I do.
Gladly.
Is it time for an inventory check or something?
Uh... I'm not sure?
No, sir. I had something else in mind.
I think it's time to stop talking.
Get over here.
Very well, sir.
Hmm. I suppose it's wrong to hope that the rest of the squad gets behind on their reports again soon. Is it time to get back to work?
Dorne? Blast it, where are you?
Hm. I think our time is up for now.
This was fantastic. Let's not wait too long for next time.
Kaasi brandy, aged thirty years. One of the few personal effects I brought with me when I defected.
I waged a veritable war to have it returned once my legal status was established. It's all but impossible to find in Republic space--I want you to have it.
I'm speechless, Elara. Thank you very much.
That's very generous.
I can' t accept this, Elara. It's too generous.
No, it's too much.
Personnel guidelines state that gifts priced at less than two hundred credits are perfectly acceptable. I purchased this bottle for the equivalent of eighty-five Republic credits.
I never took you for much of a drinker, Elara.
You like brandy?
I'm no great cantina patron, perhaps. But I can enjoy a fine spirit over dinner or some light reading just as much as the next person.
You've been a fine commander and a very good friend to me.
A token of appreciation seemed quite overdue. Don't hesitate to share if you should decide to open it.
We've been through quite a bit, haven't we, sir?
Since I joined Havoc Squad, I've seen more combat and performed more medical treatments than in my entire career beforehand. I've learned a great deal.
I'm glad you're getting some good experience here.
That's good to hear.
First-hand experience is always the best.
There's still plenty of work for Havoc to do.
We're not done yet.
Yes, sir--plenty of opportunities to improve my skills even further.
Are you gunning for a promotion or something?
Looking for a raise?
No, sir. I'm merely expressing how much I've benefitted from my time here.
I couldn't be prouder to be a part of Havoc Squad. I'm serving the Republic and becoming a better soldier and medic every day.
And I have you to thank for it all. Most officers would never have given me this chance, but you did--thank you.
You earned it, Elara. Nothing more to be said.
You're welcome.
There can be quite a distance from earning something to receiving it. I owe you my gratitude.
I just picked you for your looks. The skills are a bonus.
[Joke] You're good-looking.
Perhaps I only took the position because of your looks.
I didn't want Havoc to be all men. The skills are a nice bonus, though.
[Joke] Needed a woman.
Very funny.
Enough talk--let's put some of this experience to work, shall we?
Is that all you needed, Dorne?
Are we done here?
Yes, sir. Thank you for your time.
Sir? If you think you could spare a moment....
I'd just like you to know how happy I've been. Are you happy?
I enjoy every second we're together, Elara.
I am.
So do I.
Yes. Definitely happy.
You need to ask?
That's very good to hear.
Kisses in the hallways aren't enough for me, Elara.
I want more.
That's not all you see this as? I see it as companionship, support, belonging... so much.
I haven't taken the time for personal relationships since I came to the Republic. Not until now.
When I'm with you, I don't have to be the defector, or the intelligence asset. I can just be me.
You deserve to be happy.
I'm glad.
I think I'd forgotten what the feeling was like.
I imagine you've had to prove yourself a lot over the years.
That must be a relief.
I have. It's exhausting.
In any case, you've been wonderful, and I just thought it would be good to let you know. I'll let you get back to work.
How about the promiscuous nurse, or the Hutt slave girl? Maybe the Ambassador from Zeltron?
[Flirt] Or be someone else.
Ahem. Perhaps we'll have this talk another time, when you aren't so... preoccupied.
Sir! I have excellent news.
I've secured permission for us to use Form 859-RA for our after action reports, instead of the older 859-R!
How is the new one different?
What does that mean?
The form has been significantly streamlined for ease of completion. A full one-sixth shorter!
That's... definitely really exciting, Elara.
Um... great!
A one-sixth reduction in form completion time.
I can't believe you're actually excited about something like this.
You're so weird.
It's more efficient! Completion times will go down by at least one sixth.
This should result in a cumulative time savings of more than ninety minutes within four weeks. It should be quite pleasant.
Sir. I'm pleased to report that my plan to confront Ridu was a success.
When faced with the extensive contradictory documentation I'd prepared on the matter, he admitted to "misremembering" certain key facts, and will now testify appropriately.
I'm glad you were able to turn the situation around.
That's a relief.
So am I. An actual hearing would have held me away from my duties for months, at the very least.
Does this mean Kalor's case won't move forward?
What happens next?
I can only hope so.
Can you really trust this guy to tell the truth?
Are you sure of that?
I believe so. If he doesn't, I can provide ample evidence to prove the facts of the situation.
Hm. We seem to have an incoming holocall.
Dorne! This is Kalor--what is going on here? I just got word from Ridu that he's recanting his testimony!
You've got nothing on Dorne, Kalor.
Drop your inquiry.
You've done nothing but interfere in my work. I'm getting tired of it.
That's news to us, Captain.
[Lie] We had no idea.
Don't play games with me.
I'm getting tired of you calling my medic, Kalor.
Back off.
I'm just getting started.
I used to think you were cooperating with us, Elara.
But you're hiding something. And I will find out what.
I've followed every rule, shared everything I know. Why does this continue?
Kalor is just overzealous. We'll convince him eventually.
Even good men make mistakes.
I truly don't know how I'd handle this if it weren't for you.
Thank you.
I appreciate your patience, sir. Let's hope you're right.
That moron is dragging this out for no reason.
Kalor is an idiot.
I suppose he feels he's simply doing his duty. Speaking of which, we should really get back to our own.
We've got more important things to be doing.
Worry about it later.
You're right, sir.
Thanks again for your help.
Sir, I need to speak with you urgently. It's Captain Kalor.
He's trying to open a formal inquiry into my status as a defector. If it proceeds, I could be pulled from active duty.
Does Captain Kalor really have that kind of authority?
Can he do that?
He cannot directly order that I be suspended, no. But he can begin the necessary inquiry to do so, and guide its progress.
No need to worry, darling.
It'll be okay.
This is a very serious situation. Sir.
I'm not losing you to some desk jockey.
That won't happen.
Let's hope not, sir.
I think it's time Kalor disappeared.
Let's just kill this jerk.
Kalor may be frustrating, but there is certainly no cause for killing him.
Kalor's message said that testimony from a civilian security officer on Taris "forced" him to proceed with the inquiry. The officer's name is Ridu.
He temporarily commanded my squad during a Republic Senator's visit. The Senator was killed, and Ridu is blaming me for the mistakes he made.
How do we clear this situation up?
What can we do?
What happened? Rakghouls?
How did the Senator die?
Correct. Security details were far below required strength--Ridu didn't wish to portray Taris as a dangerous place. Fool.
He can't testify if he goes missing out in the wastelands.
So make him disappear.
I appreciate that you want to help me, but we will not commit murder to do it.
I need to speak to Ridu on Taris. I have a right to face my accuser--and I intend to do so.
I'd best set out and deal with this right away. The sooner the matter is settled, the better our chances of avoiding Kalor's inquiry.
I should set out as soon as it's convenient. The sooner this matter is attended to, the better our chances of avoiding Kalor's inquiry.
Could I speak with you privately for a moment?
I just need you to know, sir, that I've become quite fond of you. You've helped me far more than anyone I've ever known.
Because of this I'm forced to ask if, perhaps, you might feel the same fondness for me?
I think you're an amazing woman, Elara.
I do.
See if you can guess.
What do you think? [Kiss her]
Mmm... yes, I get the impression that you aren't entirely impartial to me.
I only want you to be at your best, Dorne. Nothing more.
This is strictly professional.
Oh. I--I apologize, sir. I misunderstood your intentions. I won't delay you any longer. Thank you.
There's no need to apologize, Dorne.
No problem.
Thank you, sir.
I'm sorry, I didn't mean to say I don't have feelings for you. I do.
Wait, I do care for you!
Oh. That's... that's a relief.
I'm just--Personnel Code Section Two discourages romantic relationships between personnel, particularly commanding officers.
I want to spend more time with you. But I don't want to negatively affect squad performance.
We're both mature adults, Elara. I'm sure we can stay professional.
We can handle ourselves.
Our service records would suggest that we're fully capable of navigating complex situations.
This could be a risky move.
[Flirt] You might be right.
On the other hand....
You're allowed to put yourself first sometimes, Elara.
Forget the squad.
You're right, sir.
Personnel Code Section One encourages personnel to spend time together socially. Correlations between interpersonal compatibility and unit performance are strongly positive....
We should probably return to our duties. But I think this is the right choice.
Carry on, Dorne.
Dismissed.
Yes, sir.
I'm afraid I have another requisition form that requires your attention, sir.
Our shipboard rations have fallen somewhat below the levels outlined in code eighteen, and the Quartermaster Corps restocking estimate is currently nine weeks.
As an alternative, I'd like to supplement our food stores with products from public sources--"real food", as Jorgan would say. But commanding officer approval is required.
Can't hurt to mix up the menu a bit. Make it happen.
You've got it.
If we could've been having real food this whole time, why haven't we?
What's the catch?
In the past, restocking through official channels was the simpler option. But demand is much higher now.
I'll have us back to standard stock levels in no time. Thank you for your time, sir.
Do whatever you want, Dorne. This stuff isn't worth my time.
I really don't care.
Very well, sir.
I'm still quite concerned about Captain Kalor and his accusations, sir.
If Personnel Division thinks I'm withholding information about the Empire they can continue hounding me under Security Regulation Fifteen.
I think if men like Kalor had their way, I'd be locked in a room reciting the minutia of Imperial culture until the end of time.
You'll get a lot more done in the field.
What a waste.
I couldn't agree more.
I won't let them do that to you, Elara.
That won't happen.
Thank you. I truly appreciate everything you do for me.
I do sometimes wonder if I'm being unfair, though. I'm one of the only people in the Republic with extensive knowledge of Imperial culture.
Perhaps I have a responsibility to do what few others can, even if it's not what I'd like to be doing.
You shouldn't be forced to do anything.
It's your right to decide.
I'm glad I'm not the only one who feels that way.
This squad needs the best. That means you, Dorne.
Havoc needs you more.
There's certainly nowhere I'd rather be.
First-hand information can save a lot of lives.
Can you blame them?
Yes, sir. But I want to do more for our cause than spout arbitrary information.
Still, you are correct--even if it comes to such dreary ends, I'll still be serving the Republic.
You'll always do what's required of you, won't you?
You're very dutiful.
I will, sir. So long as I have no moral objections, of course.
That may never happen, Dorne. Don't worry about it.
It's a moot point.
True enough, sir.
Thank you for taking the time to hear me out. It's good to have someone to talk to.
I know I'm your commander, but that doesn't have to be all.
I can be more.
I hadn't... that isn't something I'm used to considering.
I really shouldn't occupy any more of your time. Thank you, sir.
I always enjoy spending time with you, Elara.
We can talk anytime.
Thank you. You're very considerate.
My free time isn't unlimited, Elara.
Don't make a habit of it.
Oh. No, of course not.
I'll leave you to return to your duties.
I appreciate you taking the time to discuss this with me, sir. I'll leave you to your other duties.
Focus on the job at hand. The rest will sort itself out.
Let's get back to work.
As you wish, sir.
Sir? I need your approval to requisition some supplies for my medical kit.
I've categorized the items by relative priority. Everything fits within our allotment under supply code eighteen, but items near the bottom of the list can wait if necessary.
Best to make sure you can still patch up my handsome face.
[Flirt] Whatever you need.
Yes, sir. I'd say your features are worthy of preservation.
A guy could get used to compliments like that.
[Flirt] You're too kind.
I would prefer they remain a novel experience.
If you'll excuse me, sir.
You know what you're doing, Dorne. Request approved.
Whatever you need.
Thank you. I'll have this submitted immediately.
What kind of supplies are we talking about?
Anything interesting?
Just restocking basic supplies.
I don't care what you requisition, Dorne.
Don't bug me with this.
I'll take that as your approval. Thank you, sir.
We're fortunate to be serving in Special Forces. We get priority when requesting supplies like these.
I've heard that regular Army units must now wait several weeks to receive high-demand items. Increased hostilities are taking their toll.
If supplies are short, we'll just have to stick closer together. Keep each other covered.
[Flirt] We'll play it safe.
I'll be glad to stay closer, sir. If that's an order.
Was that... were you just flirting with me?
Are you flirting with me?
I see no reason I shouldn't be free to flirt if you do. Provided it doesn't interfere with operational effectiveness, of course. Sir.
The closer the better, Dorne.
[Flirt] Sounds good.
Understood. Sir.
You just can't resist me, Dorne. Admit it.
[Flirt] I knew you liked me.
I wouldn't go that far, sir. I'd best get on with submitting this requisition now.
If we don't get hurt, we won't need to use medical supplies.
We'll play it safe.
I'll still keep us fully stocked. Just in case.
Thank you, sir.
It's probably going to get worse before it gets better.
Things are getting messy.
That does seem to be the path we're on. Hopefully our actions can at least stem the tide.
I'd best get this finished, sir. Thank you for your time.
I want Havoc fully supplied at all times, Dorne. Whatever it takes.
Make sure we stay stocked.
Yes, sir. I'll do everything I can.
Sir? I'm sorry to bother you, but I've received a troubling message from Captain Kalor, my supervisory officer from Personnel Division.
He ordered me to contact him immediately. I hoped you could join me for the conversation.
I'd be glad to.
Of course.
I've got a few minutes, at least.
I guess I could.
Thank you very much, sir. I'll raise him on the holo now.
Kalor really needs to give this up.
Not this again.
Hopefully he's decided to approach our situation more rationally.
Captain Kalor. This is Elara Dorne, personnel number 22-795, reporting in per your request.
Always the whole mess. Every time... heh, anyway, yes, thank you for returning my call, Elara.
It's about this whole situation with your brother. You did a great job, obviously, but people are starting to think you have more information than you're sharing.
We got a lead, and Elara acted on it. End of story.
That's nonsense.
Maybe, maybe not.
If Elara has any more intel for you, she'll share it.
Elara will cooperate fully.
Havoc Squad doesn't have time for your pointless accusations.
Back off.
I'm sorry you feel that my job is pointless, but it's still my job.
Elara, if you have information you'd like to share, I think this would be a good time for you to come in.
I appreciate the offer, but I have no further information of value to you.
Suit yourself. I have work to do--Kalor out.
He's still demanding more, after everything I've done. What do I have to do to prove myself?
You're a good soldier, Elara. You've got nothing to prove.
Nothing.
Thank you, sir. But I think it's clear that some people don't feel the same way.
He can't touch us, Elara. Forget him.
Kalor is all talk.
I hope you're right.
Let's just get back to work. I'd rather focus on something else for a while.
We've got more important things to do right now.
Forget it.
Yes, sir. I could stand to think about something else for a while.
The operation was a complete success, sir. Per code twenty-three of the enemy interaction guidelines, Aleksei officially defected to the Galactic Republic.
Given the circumstances, we didn't have much time to catch up... but I have my brother back. Thank you for allowing me to help him.
I'm happy to hear that everything worked out.
That's great news!
Are you certain this isn't just an Imperial scam?
You're sure he's being honest?
I'm quite certain--my brother isn't leading us on.
I did you a huge favor here. Don't forget it.
You owe me.
I don't think I could ever forget something like this, sir.
Hopefully Personnel Division will allow me to stay in contact with Aleksei--not privately, of course--and help guide him through the defection process.
I should start compiling notes for him. Thanks again, sir.
Sir. I need to speak to you immediately. I've received a strange holomessage that appears to bear Imperial signal codes.
I haven't watched it yet. I wanted you present to supervise and confirm that I'm not engaged in secret communications with Imperial personnel.
We'd better watch it immediately.
Sounds urgent.
Yes, sir. I'll load it now.
That's silly. You could've watched the thing first.
You worry too much.
Someone in my position can never be too cautious. Let's see, now....
How could the Imperials send a message to you?
This is very suspicious.
I don't have the slightest idea. It should be impossible. Let's find out what this is all about....
Elara. It's me. Aleksei. I... I hope you're well. It's been a long time.
Aleksei... sir. This message is from my brother. I don't know what to say.
You don't need to say anything. Let's hear the rest of the message first.
Keep playing it.
I know this must be hard for you.
Take your time.
It's more surprising than anything. I honestly never thought I'd see his face again.
You're telling me you had nothing to do with your brother contacting you?
Are you trying to fool me?
Of course not! I haven't spoken with Aleksei since well before I defected. I have no idea how he could have sent this.
I'm sorry to contact you like this, but I need your help. My men and I... we're as good as dead.
We're on Nar Shaddaa--we were caught tampering with one of the Hutts' operations. We never dreamed the slugs would have so much security.
These Hutts are Imperial allies, Elara. There is no rescue team. We'll be disavowed and left to die. Please--you're my only hope now.
How do we know Aleksei isn't leading us into a trap?
Can we trust him?
We should proceed with caution. But I don't believe my brother is lying to us.
Get your brother out of there, Elara. You've got my leave.
You can go help him.
I... thank you, sir. I appreciate your willingness to help, given the circumstances.
We can't help Imperial personnel, Elara.
This is out of the question.
There is no regulation against assisting the enemy so long as they aren't acting against Republic interests.
I believe I can bring him to our side. I know my brother better than anyone--I can convince him to defect.
Perhaps it's best if I see to this matter alone, sir. Alexei will be much easier to convince if he doesn't feel outnumbered.
If you can bring him in willingly, then all the better.
Sounds good.
I'm going out on a limb here, Dorne. Don't let me down.
If you say so.
I won't, sir. You can count on me.
If your brother won't flip, you'll bring him in as a prisoner. Understood?
Don't go soft on him.
Yes, sir.
Coordinates are included at the end of the message. I'll prep my gear for search-and-rescue.
Time is critical. Please inform me as soon as I'm cleared to set out.
If I may say so, sir, you've had quite an impressive career. You're the commander of the most elite squad in the entire Republic--you must be quite proud.
Serving in Havoc Squad has been the greatest honor of my career.
Yes, I'm very proud.
I just go where they tell me and do my job. Nothing more.
Just another assignment.
Clearly you do more than that, or you wouldn't have such an exceptional service record.
I want to command thousands of men, not just one squad.
I'd prefer a higher position.
I should think serving as commander of Havoc Squad would allow you first choice of many command positions in the long run.
I remember when I first enlisted and qualified for medical specialization. My brother Aleksei completed his technical specialization on the same day.
We were both proud to finally serve in the Imperial military. My brother advanced quickly, but I became disillusioned as time went on.
Why did you become disillusioned?
What changed your mind?
Is Aleksei still in the Imperial military?
Is your brother still serving?
As far as I know, yes. I wish he'd seen things as I did.
I don't see how anyone could serve the Empire for long.
You'd be a fool not to.
Cultural indoctrination is a powerful force.
The Imperial military was supposed to stand for honor and discipline. But my superiors discarded those concepts any time a Sith asked it.
I'd always been taught that the Jedi and the Republic were genocidal hypocrites. But the only brutalities I witnessed were committed by my own comrades.
Did you try to change things? Or did you defect right away?
What did you do?
I'm sure it wasn't easy to learn the truth like that.
A harsh realization.
I have always preferred difficult truths to easy lies.
How can anyone believe such obvious lies?
"Genocidal hypocrites"!
Given the right point of view, anything can be rationalized. I'm just glad I could see things for how they really were.
I raised my concerns with my superiors, but they only questioned my resolve.
Soon I would've been forced to prove my loyalty by carrying out orders directly against my conscience. I chose to defect instead.
I'd say you made the right move, Dorne.
Sounds wise.
Once I'd made the decision, I slipped away during my squad's next night patrol. I was gone before anyone realized it.
Did you have any trouble getting away from the rest of your unit?
Was it hard to escape?
I had noted numerous inefficiencies in our assigned patrol routes--I simply took advantage of one of them to escape.
I hope you took out some other Imps in the process.
Did you sabotage anything?
I thought it best to simply slip away unnoticed during a night patrol.
I surrendered to the first Republic patrol I came across and declared my intention to defect. That was over three years ago.
It's strange to realize how long it's been. The Republic truly feels like my home now.
Sir? I wondered if I might ask a personal question--about the former Havoc Squad members' defection.
What was it like to have your commander and comrades join the enemy? How did you feel?
I was shocked--I never saw it coming.
Surprised.
Tavus and the others must have been hiding their plans very carefully.
It was hard to see such great soldiers throwing away everything they'd fought for.
Sad.
I can only imagine what it must've been like.
I would've torn them apart with my bare hands if I could have.
Furious.
An understandable reaction.
I've always wondered how my family took the news of my defection. It must've been difficult for them to understand.
Your family is still in the Empire?
They didn't come with you?
Oh, yes. The Dornes are very proud of their history within the Empire.
What was your family like?
Tell me about them.
Austere. Proud. Warm, as well, at least in private.
That part of your life is over. Focus on the present.
Put that behind you.
That's easier said than done.
Members of the Dorne family have served with distinction in the Imperial military for generations. It's an important family tradition.
It isn't easy to reach prominence in the Empire with no aptitude for the Force, but my family did it. I hope they're all still well.
It can't be easy to fight against your family's side.
It must be hard on you.
It is a consequence I accepted when I chose to defect. I don't give it a second thought.
Your family got by before you came along. They'll be alright.
I'm sure they're fine.
You're probably right, sir.
You betrayed the Empire. Your family probably paid the consequences for it.
They're probably dead.
I'm sure they suffer under surveillance now, just as I do. But I doubt anyone was executed.
The Empire may be a harsh place, but it's rarely as irrational as you assume.
Sir. I... feel I owe you an apology. After we spoke with Captain Kalor, I was unnecessarily curt with you.
You've been very supportive. That hasn't always been the case with Republic personnel I've dealt with since defecting.
I wouldn't be much of a CO if I didn't watch out for my people.
You're part of my team.
It's greatly appreciated, sir.
It must be hard to work with people who don't trust you.
I'm sorry it's been so tough.
I expected some degree of reservation, but nothing like what I've actually encountered.
People have a hard time forgetting what the Empire has done to us.
Surely you aren't surprised.
I wouldn't expect anyone to forget. But I didn't do any of those things.
People distrust me as soon as I speak. They only hear my accent.
Even when I'm not a potential spy, I'm a resource. Endless questions about Imperial culture, personnel, military procedures... it's exhausting.
You're a good soldier, Dorne. Don't worry about what other people expect.
Don't let it get you down.
Thank you, sir. I really don't complain by nature.
You could be locked up somewhere answering those questions.
Could be worse.
You're right, of course. I've been given a very great opportunity.
Are you trying to say you regret switching sides?
What are you trying to say?
Of course not. I apologize--I shouldn't let such things frustrate me.
Mistrust and inconvenience are a small price to pay for a clear conscience. I don't regret defecting to the Republic at all.
Despite my past, I was allowed to join the military, earn commendations and serve in the Republic's most elite squad. I'm very fortunate.
The Republic is lucky to have you.
You've earned it all.
Thank you. I'm very proud to be here.
What led you to defect in the first place?
Why did you change sides?
We should talk about it later, sir. I've occupied enough of your time.
If that's all, Dorne, I need to get back to work.
Are we done here?
Of course, sir. Thank you for your time.
Excuse me, sir. May I have a moment of your time?
What can I do for you, Dorne?
Go ahead.
I've always got time for you, Elara.
[Flirt] Of course.
Ahem. Thank you, sir.
I've always got time, Elara. What do you need?
Of course!
Thrill me, Dorne. What do you want?
This had better be important.
As a condition of my service in the Republic military, Personnel Division requires that I report regularly on my activities.
However, my Havoc Squad missions are classified and cannot be shared with Personnel Division. I'd like to ask if you would vouch for me when I report in.
I'll be happy to help.
I'd be glad to.
Thank you very much, sir. We should use the ship's secure line.
Haven't you proven your loyalty by now?
Why the scrutiny?
That is a matter for Personnel Division to decide. We should use the ship's secure holocomm.
I don't have all day. Make it fast.
Keep it quick.
Yes, sir. We'll use the ship's secure holocommunicator.
Captain Kalor? This is Elara Dorne, personnel number 22-795, reporting in per regulation 449.
Please, Elara, you don't have to give me the full rundown every time. I know who you are. How are things?
Well enough, sir. Allow me to introduce you to the commander of Havoc Squad--my new CO. Sir, this is Captain Kalor, Army Personnel Division.
Good to meet you, Captain.
Hello.
The pleasure is mine. Meeting you is a real honor.
I don't see that Dorne's loyalty needs to be proven further.
Is this necessary, Captain?
Oh, we're all very proud of Elara. This is just part of the process.
I know this is all part of the job, Captain, but we have places to be.
Let's get this over with.
Tell me about being in the top squad in the Republic, Elara. You must be keeping very busy.
I'm sorry, Captain, but you aren't authorized to know about Havoc Squad's activities. My CO will have to vouch for me from now on.
What? Elara, I don't want to be a hard case, but rules are rules--this "top secret" junk won't fly.
All Havoc Squad activities are highly classified, Captain. I'm sorry for any inconvenience.
Elara is right.
Heh. Inconvenience.
This is how it is, Captain. You don't like it, talk to General Garza.
Get over it.
I might have to. This situation is not acceptable.
Don't try to push us, desk jockey. It won't end well.
You're out of line.
Are you insane? You're actually threatening me?
Just... just carry on, Elara. We'll talk about this after I've had a word with my superiors. Kalor out.
Hm. I wasn't expecting him to react so strongly. Surely he didn't expect me to report on classified information?
Protecting classified information is a top priority.
You did the right thing.
Yes, sir. I'm surprised the captain didn't agree.
Do you think Kalor will actually get the clearance he needs?
What happens now?
I really don't know.
You can't expect much out of a soldier who doesn't even fight.
Kalor is a waste of space.
I have to disagree. Wars are won as much through organization as combat success, and specialists are needed for both.
If you'll excuse me, sir, I have several matters to attend to. Thank you for your time.
Sir? I'd appreciate it if we could speak privately, perhaps the next time we return to the ship.
Sir? I'd appreciate it if I could have a word with you at our next opportunity.
Sir.
I'd rather not talk right now, sir.
I'll try to keep this short.
I'll follow your lead whenever you're ready.
We can discuss non-mission-critical issues later.
Let's move on, shall we?
Good day to you.
I'm with you, sir.
That's easier said than done.
First-hand experience is always the best.
Certainly.
Hmm. If you wish, sir.
Yes, sir. I'll do everything I can.
Agreed.
I'm on it, sir.
